title-group.article-title: Chronic treatment with selective I2-imidazoline receptor ligands decreases the content of pro-apoptotic markers in rat brain

contrib-group.aff: Laboratori de Neurofarmacologia, Institut Universitari d’Investigació en Ciències de la Salut (IUNICS), Universitat de les Illes Balears, Palma de Mallorca, and Redes Temáticas de Investigación Cooperativa en Salud-Red de Trastornos Adictivos (RETICS-RTA), Spain

author-notes.corresp: Jesús A García-Sevilla, Laboratory of Neuropharmacology, IUNICS, University of the Balearic Islands, Cra. Valldemossa km 7.5, E-07122 Palma de Mallorca, Spain. Email: jesus.garcia-sevilla@uib.es

abstract.p: Selective I2-imidazoline receptor ligands induce neuroprotection through various molecular mechanisms including blockade of N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors. To investigate new neuroprotective mechanisms associated with I2-imidazoline receptors, the effects of selective (2-styryl-2-imidazoline (LSL 61122), 2-(2-benzofuranyl)-2-imidazoline (2-BFI), 2-(4,5-dihydroimidazol-2-yl) quinoline hydrochloride (BU-224)) and non-selective (idazoxan) I2-drugs on canonical apoptotic pathways were assessed in rat brain cortex. The acute treatment with LSL 61122 (10 mg/kg) reduced the content of mitochondrial (pro-apoptotic) Bax (-33%) and cytochrome c (-31%), which was prevented by idazoxan, an I2-receptor antagonist. The sustained stimulation of I2-imidazoline receptors with selective drugs (10 mg/kg, every 12 h for seven days) was associated with down-regulation of key components of the extrinsic (Fas receptor: -20%; Fas associated protein with death domain (FADD) adaptor: -47–54%) and/or intrinsic (Bax: -20–23%; cytochrome c: -22–28%) apoptotic signalling and/or up-regulation of survival anti-apoptotic factors (p-Ser194 FADD/FADD ratio: +1.6-2.5-fold; and/or Bcl-2/Bax ratio: +1.5-fold), which in the long-term could dampen cell death in the brain. Similar chronic treatments with LSL 60101 (the imidazole analogue of 2-BFI) and idazoxan (a mixed I2/α2-ligand) did not induce significant alterations of pro- or anti-apoptotic proteins. The disclosed anti-apoptotic mechanisms of selective I2-imidazoline drugs may work in concert with other molecular mechanisms of neuroprotection (e.g. blockade of NMDA receptors) that are engaged by I2-ligands.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: During the past decades the pharmacological characterisation of imidazoline binding sites, recognized by imidazol(ine)-guanidine compounds, has defined a novel family of putative receptors comprising the I1-, I2- and I3-types for which agmatine is an endogenous ligand (Regunathan and Reis, 1996; Eglen et al., 1998; Morgan and Chan, 2001; Uzbay, 2012). Intensive research has been devoted to the biochemical and structural characterisation of imidazoline-binding proteins (Escribá et al., 1995, 1999; Raddatz et al., 1995, 1997; Piletz et al., 2000; Molderings et al., 2007; Kimura et al., 2009) and their second-messenger systems (Separovic et al., 1996; Greney et al., 2000; Edwards et al., 2001; Lui et al., 2010), but much remains to be elucidated. Nonetheless, agmatine and imidazoline receptor ligands induce several biological activities with great therapeutic potential (Head and Mayorov, 2006; Smith et al., 2009; Li and Zhang, 2011).

The development of highly selective I2-imidazoline ligands (>1500-fold selectivity for I2-sites over α2-adrenoceptors), such as 2-styryl-2-imidazoline (LSL 61122; valldemossine or tracizoline) (García-Sevilla et al., 1993; Ozaita et al., 1997; Pigini et al., 1997), 2-(2-benzofuranyl)-2-imidazoline (2-BFI) (Nutt et al., 1995) and its quinoline analogue 2-(4,5-dihydroimidazol-2-yl)quinoline hydrochloride (BU-224) (Hudson et al., 1997, 1999), has been instrumental in characterising I2-binding sites and their functions. I2-imidazoline receptors are widely distributed in the brain (Miralles et al., 1993; Alemany et al., 1997; Lione et al., 1998; Kawamura et al., 2011) and found in both neurones and glial cells (Regunathan et al., 1993; Olmos et al., 1994; Ruggiero et al., 1998). Notably, selective I2-receptor ligands modulate morphine-induced analgaesia and display relevant antinociceptive activity (Boronat et al., 1998; Sánchez-Blázquez et al., 2000; Gentili et al., 2006; Ferrari et al., 2011; Li et al., 2011; Li and Zhang, 2011). Moreover, alterations of I2-receptors have been associated with various psychiatric and neurodegenerative disorders (García-Sevilla et al., 1999; Smith et al., 2009). Remarkably, stimulation of I2-receptors can promote various neuroprotective actions in rats and mice (Boronat et al., 1998; Qiu and Zheng, 2006; Wang et al., 2011). Thus, selective I2-ligands were shown to induce neuroprotection in various models of neurotoxicity through blockade of N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors (Olmos et al., 1996, 1999; Milhaud et al., 2000; Jiang et al., 2010), activation of glial cells and production of neurotrophic factors (Olmos et al., 1994; Alemany et al., 1995; Casanovas et al., 2000) or lysosomal membrane stabilization in astrocytes (Choi et al., 2002).

Other mechanisms of neuroprotection induced by imidazoline drugs may involve the regulation of mitochondrial apoptotic proteins or caspase-3 activity (Dontenwill et al., 2003; Dupuy et al., 2004; Han et al., 2010). Apoptosis is mediated by the extrinsic or death receptor pathway (Lossi and Merighi, 2003) and the intrinsic or mitochondrial pathway (Galluzzi et al., 2009). Thus, apoptosis requires the formation of a death-inducing signalling complex (DISC) (e.g. Fas receptor–Fas- associated death domain (FADD) adaptor, initiator caspase-8 and FADD-like interleukin-1β-converting enzyme-inhibitory protein (FLIPL)) as well as the involvement of pro-apoptotic mitochondrial factors (e.g. Bax, cytochrome c) that detect and amplify the signals of death receptors. These apoptotic pathways converge to activate executioner caspases (e.g. caspase-3) that cleave vital substrates leading to cell death (Kumar, 2007). Importantly, Fas-FADD complex and p-Ser194 FADD can also induce non-apoptotic signals (e.g. neuroplasticity) in the brain (Tourneur and Chiocchia, 2010; Ramos-Miguel et al., 2011).

To further investigate new signalling pathways and neuroprotective mechanisms associated with I2-imidazoline receptors, the acute and chronic effects of selective and non-selective I2-drugs on the main components of the extrinsic and intrinsic apoptotic pathways, the activation of pro-apoptotic c-Jun NH2-terminal protein kinase (JNK; Dhanasekaran and Reddy, 2008) and the integrity of the DNA repair enzyme poly-(ADP-ribose)- polymerase-1 (PARP-1; Chaitanya et al., 2010) were assessed in the rat brain.

sec.title: Drugs
sec.p: LSL 61122 (2-styryl-2-imidazoline trans form HCl; valldemossine or tracizoline), LSL 60101 [2-(2-benzofuranyl)-2-imidazol HCl], and idazoxan HCl were kindly provided by Ipsen Pharma S.A. (Barcelona, Spain) and the compound retested for structural integrity (1H nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy) at the University of the Balearic Islands (UIB) core facilities (Dr Gabriel Martorell). 2-BFI [2-(2-benzofuranyl)-2-imidazoline HCl] and its quinoline analogue BU-224 [2-(4,5-dihydroimidazol-2-yl)-quinoline HCl] were purchased from Tocris Bioscience (Avonmouth, UK). All drugs were dosed as HCl salts. The chemical structures of these compounds, their affinities at I2-imidazoline receptors and α2-adrenoceptors, and their selectivity for I2-receptors are shown in Table 1.

caption.p: Chemical structures of I2-imidazoline ligands, radioligand binding affinities at I2-imidazoline receptors and α2-adrenoceptors (Ki values in mammal brain tissue) and α2/I2 drug selectivity.

tr.td: Ipsen Pharma dataOzaita et al., 1997Pigini et al., 1997
Eglen et al., 1998Ipsen Pharma dataAlemany et al., 1997Ozaita et al., 1997Boronat et al., 1998Lione et al., 1998Anderson et al., 2005

fn.p: Radioligands used: [3H]2-BFI or [3H]idazoxan in the presence of (-)-adrenaline for I2-imidazoline receptors, and [3H]RX821002 or [3H]UK14304 (only idazoxan) for α2-adrenoceptors. RX821002, 2-(2-methoxy-1,4-benzodioxan-2-yl)-2-imidazoline, also known as 2-methoxy idazoxan. UK14304, 5-bromo-6(2-imidazolin-2-ylamino)quinoxaline, also known as brimonidine.

sec.title: Animals and treatments
sec.p: Adult male Sprague-Dawley rats (200–250 g) were used. The animals were housed in methacrylate cages, three rats per cage, with wood shavings (Ultrasorb, Panlab s.l., Barcelona, Spain) under controlled conditions of temperature (21°C), humidity (70%) and light/dark cycle (light period: 08:00 to 20:00 h), and they had free access to a standard diet (Panlab A04) and tap water. All animal care and experimental procedures were conducted according to standard ethical guidelines (European Communities Council Directive 86/609/EEC) and approved by the Local Bioethical Committee (UIB). All efforts were made to minimise the number of animals used and their suffering.

For the acute drug treatments, groups of randomly allocated rats received intraperitoneal (i.p.) injections (1 ml/kg body weight) of LSL 61122, 2-BFI, BU-224, LSL 60101 or idazoxan (10 mg/kg, 2 h; n=7 for each group). Other groups of rats received idazoxan (10 mg/kg, i.p.) 30 min before LSL 61122 (10 mg/kg, i.p.) to antagonise the acute effects (2 h) of the I2-selective drug (n=5 for each group). For the chronic experiments the rats were treated with the LSL 61122, 2-BFI, BU-224, LSL 60101 or idazoxan (10 × 10 mg/kg, i.p., 12 h apart) for seven days (n=7 for each group). Control rats (n=5–10) received 0.9% NaCl (saline; 1 ml/kg, i.p.) in parallel to drug treatments. The acute and chronic dose regimens of I2-drugs, and the duration of treatment, were chosen from previous neurochemical (dose-response) studies in rats (e.g. see Alemany et al., 1995). The animals were killed without anaesthesia by decapitation at the indicated times. The brains were rapidly removed and the cerebral cortex dissected on ice, frozen in liquid nitrogen and then stored at -80°C until the neurochemical assays.

sec.title: Sample preparation, Western blot analysis and quantification of target proteins
sec.p: Rat cortical samples were prepared for Western blot analysis as described by García-Fuster et al. (2003, 2007). Protein concentration in cortical homogenates was determined with BCA (bicinchoninic acid) assay kit (Pierce Biotechnology, Rockford, IL, USA). Brain proteins (40 µg of total homogenate) were resolved by gel electrophoresis on 10–12% sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS)-polyacrylamide minigels (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Hercules, CA, USA), which was followed by protein electrotransferred to nitrocellulose membranes (Bio-Rad Laboratories) and other immunoblot standard procedures (García-Fuster et al., 2007). For the quantification of Fas receptor forms, the transfer buffer also contained 0.1% SDS to better resolve the expression of Fas receptor aggregates (Álvaro-Bartolomé et al., 2010). After blocking nonspecific protein-binding sites, the membranes were incubated overnight at 4°C in blocking solution with the primary antibody of interest, and the blots were developed with peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibodies, including anti-rabbit or anti-mouse IgG at 1:5,000 dilution for 1 h at 24°C. The primary antibodies with immunoaffinity-purified epitopes are described in Table 2, and were used at the appropriate dilutions (1:750–1:10,000).

caption.p: Antibodies used for the detection and quantification of apoptotic proteins and other signalling molecules in rat brain.

fn.p: FADD: Fas associated protein with death domain; FLIP: FADD-like interleukin-1β-converting enzyme-inhibitory protein; JNK 1/2: c-Jun NH2-terminal protein kinase 1/2; PARP-1: poly-(ADP-ribose)-polymerase-1.

sec.p: The characterisation and validation of the primary antibodies in brain tissue have been reported in previous studies (García-Fuster et al., 2003, 2007, 2008a, 2008b). In particular, Fas receptor was immunodetected as monomeric (~37 kDa), glycosylated (~48–52 kDa) and aggregated (~116–200 kDa) forms in brain tissue. Total FADD was detected as dimeric forms (~51 kDa) and p-Ser194 FADD as oligomeric forms (~116 kDa).

Bound antibody, representing specific immunoreactivity, was detected with an enhanced chemiluminescence (ECL) detection system (Amersham, Buckinghamshire, UK) and visualised by exposure to autoradiographic film (Amersham ECL Hyperfilm). The intensity of protein bands on autoradiograms, measured as integrated optical density, was quantified by densitometric scanning (GS-800 Imaging Densitometer, Bio-Rad Laboratories) as described by García-Fuster et al. (2007). The amount of a target protein in brain samples of rats treated with I2-imidazoline drugs was compared in the same gel with that of control saline rats. The quantification procedure was repeated three to six times in different gels (each gel with different brain samples from saline- and drug-treated rats). Finally, percentage changes in immunoreactivity with respect to control samples (100%) were calculated for each rat treated with the specific drug in the various gels and the mean value used as a final estimate. As a control for sample loading and protein transfer, the blots were stripped (Boronat et al., 2001) and reprobed with anti-β-actin monoclonal antibody, and target protein content was normalised to that of β-actin. Activation of JNK1/2 (p-Thr183/Tyr185) was expressed as the ratio of p-protein to total protein and reported as a percentage of that in the corresponding control group.

sec.title: Functional assay for apoptotic cell death
sec.p: Poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase-1 (PARP-1) is a sensor of DNA damage with major roles in DNA repair (Chaitanya et al., 2010). The proteolytic cleavage of nuclear PARP-1 in brain cortex of rats treated with saline or I2-imidazoline drugs was monitored with the PARP Cleavage Detection Kit (Calbiochem, Dramstadt, Germany). The death substrate PARP-1 (116 kDa) is cleaved into a specific 85 kDa fragment after activation of caspase-3, which greatly counteracts PARP function as a DNA repairing enzyme (Chaitanya et al., 2010). The contents of PARP-1 and fragment were quantified by Western blot analysis (García-Fuster et al., 2008b).

sec.title: Data and statistical analysis
sec.p: All series of data were analysed with GraphPad PrismTM software, version 4.0 (GraphPad Software, Inc, San Diego, CA, USA). Results are expressed as mean values ± standard error of the mean (SEM). One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) with a Bonferroni’s post hoc test (multiple comparisons), and Student’s two-tailed t-test were used for the statistical evaluations. The level of significance was chosen as p ≤0.05.

sec.title: Acute and chronic effects of I2-imidazoline ligands on Fas receptor, FADD adaptor and other death-inducing signalling components (DISC) in the brain
sec.p: The acute treatment of rats with LSL 61122 (10 mg/kg, 2 h), compared with saline solution administration, decreased the content of Fas receptor aggregates (26%) and p-Ser194 FADD (26%) in brain cortex (Figure 1A). Acute LSL 61122 did not alter the content of monomeric or glycosylated Fas (data not shown) or that of FADD adaptor (Figure 1A). Chronic treatment with LSL 61122 (10 mg/kg, every 12 h for seven days) was not associated with significant changes in Fas receptor forms, FADD or p-Ser194 FADD (Figure 1A).

caption.p: Acute and chronic effects of (A) LSL 61122, (B) 2-BFI and (C) BU-224 on Fas receptor, FADD adaptor and p-Ser194 FADD immunodensities in rat cerebral cortex. Groups of treatments: saline (n=10), acute I2-drugs (10 mg/kg, i.p., 2 h; n=7), chronic I2-drugs (10 mg/kg, i.p., every 12 h for seven days; n=7). Columns are means±SEM of n experiments per group with an animal per experiment, and expressed as a percentage of saline-treated rats (control group). One-way ANOVA detected significant differences between the groups of treatments for each I2-drug and target protein, except in A for FADD (F values, at least p <0.01). *p <0.05 **p <0.01; ***p <0.001 when compared with the corresponding control group (ANOVA followed by Bonferroni’s test). Right panels (A, B, C): representative immunoblots of Fas receptor aggregates, dimeric FADD and oligomeric p-Ser194 FADD for each set of experiments, and a representative immunoblot for β-actin as a loading control (saline samples in duplicate; I2-drug samples in triplicate). The molecular masses of target proteins were estimated from referenced standards.

LSL: 2-styryl-2-imidazoline; BFI: 2-(2-benzofuranyl)-2-imidazoline; BU-224: 2-(4,5-dihydroimidazol-2-yl)quinolinehydrochloride; FADD: Fas associated protein with death domain; i.p.: intraperitoneal; ANOVA: analysis of variance.

sec.p: Acute 2-BFI (10 mg/kg, 2 h) increased Fas receptor aggregates (51%), FADD (35%) and p-Ser194 FADD (40%) in rat brain cortex (Figure 1B). In contrast, chronic 2-BFI (10 mg/kg, every 12 h for seven days) markedly decreased FADD content (47%) without altering that of Fas aggregates or p-Ser194 FADD (Figure 1B).

Acute BU-224 (10 mg/kg, 2 h; the quinoline analogue of 2-BFI) decreased Fas receptor aggregates (15%) and p-Ser194 FADD (43%), but not FADD, in rat brain cortex (Figure 1C). Chronic BU-224 (10 mg/kg, every 12 h for seven days) reduced the content of Fas receptor aggregates (20%) and FADD (54%) but not that of p-Ser194 FADD (Figure 1C).

The acute treatments of rats (10 mg/kg, 2 h) with LSL 60101 (the imidazole analogue of 2-BFI with a lesser affinity for I2-sites; Table 1) and idazoxan (a mixed I2/α2-ligand; Table 1) did not alter the content of Fas receptor forms, FADD or p-Ser194 FADD in brain cortex (data not shown). Similarly, chronic LSL 60101 and idazoxan (10 mg/kg, every 12 h for seven days) were not associated with significant changes in the contents of Fas receptor forms and FADD adaptor in rat brain cortex (data not shown).

Notably, chronic treatment with 2-BFI and BU-224, but not LSL 61122, increased the ratio of p-Ser194 FADD to total FADD (an index of non-apoptotic activity) in the same rat cortical samples (p-FADD/FADD ratio; chronic saline: 1.01 ± 0.05; chronic 2-BFI: 1.60 ± 0.11, p < 0.001; chronic BU-224: 2.49 ± 0.39, p < 0.005; chronic LSL 61122: 1.11 ± 0.25, p > 0.05). In contrast, acute BU-224, but not 2-BFI or LSL 61122, decreased p-Ser194 FADD/FADD ratio in rat brain cortex (acute saline: 1.01 ± 0.11; acute BU 224: 0.59 ± 0.08, p < 0.05).

In the extrinsic apoptotic pathway, Fas-FADD complex together with caspase-8 and FLIPL conform to the DISC. Acute treatment with LSL 61122, but not with 2-BFI or BU-224, reduced the content of caspase-8 in rat brain cortex (22%) (Figure 2A). Acutely, these selective I2-drugs did not alter FLIPL content (Figure 2B). Chronic 2-BFI, but not BU-224, decreased the content of caspase-8 (30%) and that of FLIPL (23%) in rat brain cortex (Figure 2A). Chronic LSL 61112 was not associated with alterations of caspase-8 but it increased FLIPL content (23%) (Figure 2A and Figure 2B).

caption.p: Acute and chronic effects of LSL 61122, 2-BFI and BU-224 on (A) caspase-8 and (B) FLIPL immunodensities in rat cerebral cortex. Groups of treatments: saline (n=10), acute I2-drugs (10 mg/kg, i.p., 2 h; n=7), chronic I2-drugs (10 mg/kg, i.p., every 12 h for seven days; n=7). Columns are means±SEM of n experiments per group with an animal per experiment and expressed as a percentage of saline-treated rats (control group). One-way ANOVA detected significant differences between the groups of treatments for I2-drug and target protein, except for BU-224 (F values, at least p <0.05). *p <0.05 **p <0.01 when compared with the corresponding control group (ANOVA followed by Bonferroni’s test). Right panels (A, B): representative immunoblots of caspase-8 and FLIPL for each set of experiments and a representative immunoblot for β-actin as a loading control (saline samples in duplicate; I2-drug samples in triplicate). The molecular masses of target proteins were estimated from referenced standards.

LSL: 2-styryl-2-imidazoline; BFI: 2-(2-benzofuranyl)-2-imidazoline; BU-224: 2-(4,5-dihydroimidazol-2-yl)quinolinehydrochloride; FLIP: FADD-like interleukin-1β-converting enzyme-inhibitory protein; i.p.: intraperitoneal; ANOVA: analysis of variance.

sec.title: Acute and chronic effects of I2-imidazoline ligands on Bcl-2, Bax and cytochrome c in the brain
sec.p: The acute treatment of rats with LSL 61122 (10 mg/kg, 2 h) decreased the content of Bcl-2 (44%) and Bax (35%) in brain cortex (Figure 3A). In contrast, chronic treatment with LSL 61122 (10 mg/kg, every 12 h for seven days) markedly increased Bcl-2 content (53%) but not that of Bax (Figure 3A).

caption.p: Acute and chronic effects of (A) LSL 61122, (B) 2-BFI and (C) BU-224 on Bcl-2, Bax and cytochrome c (Cyt c) immunodensities in rat cerebral cortex. Groups of treatments: saline (n=10), acute I2-drugs (10 mg/kg, i.p., 2 h; n=7), chronic I2-drugs (10 mg/kg, i.p., every 12 h for seven days; n=7). Columns are means±SEM of n experiments per group with an animal per experiment, and expressed as a percentage of saline-treated rats (control group). One-way ANOVA detected significant differences between the groups of treatments for I2-drug and target protein, except in C for Bcl-2 (F values, at least p <0.01). *p <0.05 **p <0.01; ***p <0.001 when compared with the corresponding control group (ANOVA followed by Bonferroni’s test). Right panels (A, B, C): representative immunoblots of Bcl-2, Bax and Cyt c for each set of experiments and a representative immunoblot for β-actin as a loading control (saline samples in duplicate; I2-drug samples in triplicate). The molecular masses of target proteins were estimated from referenced standards.
LSL: 2-styryl-2-imidazoline; BFI: 2-(2-benzofuranyl)-2-imidazoline; BU-224: 2-(4,5-dihydroimidazol-2-yl)quinolinehydrochloride; i.p.: intraperitoneal; ANOVA: analysis of variance.

sec.p: Thus, chronic LSL 61122 increased the ratio of anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 to pro-apoptotic Bax (an index that measures the balance between cell survival and cell death) in brain cortex (Bcl-2/Bax ratio; saline: 0.99 ± 0.07%; LSL: 1.54 ± 0.16%, p < 0.01). Moreover, acute and chronic LSL 61122 induced significant decreases in the content of cytochrome c, a potent caspase-3 activator, in rat brain cortex (24% and 38%, respectively, p < 0.01) (Figure 3A).

Acute 2-BFI (10 mg/kg, 2 h) increased Bcl-2 content (35%) but not that of Bax in rat brain cortex (Figure 3B). Chronic 2-BFI did not alter Bcl-2 but decreased Bax (20%) (Figure 3B). Chronic 2-BFI did not significantly alter the ratio of Bcl-2 to Bax. Chronic, but not acute, 2-BFI treatment reduced cytochrome c content in brain cortex (28%) (Figure 3B).

Acute BU-224 (10 mg/kg, 2 h) did not alter the content of Bcl-2, Bax or cytochrome c in rat brain cortex (Figure 3C). However, chronic BU-224 decreased Bax (23%) and cyrochrome c (22%) content without altering that of Bcl-2 (Figure 3C). Chronic 2-BFI did not significantly alter the ratio of Bcl-2 to Bax.

Acute treatments of rats with LSL 60101 and idazoxan (see above) did not significantly alter the contents of Bcl-2, Bax and cytochrome c, or the ratio of Bcl-2 to Bax in brain cortex (data not shown). Similarly, chronic LSL 60101 and idazoxan (10 mg/kg, every 12 h for seven days) were not associated with significant changes in the content of Bcl-2 protein in rat brain cortex (data not shown).

sec.title: Prevention by idazoxan of LSL 61122-induced down-regulation of Bax and cytochrome c in the brain
sec.p: Pretreatment of rats (30 min) with idazoxan (10 mg/kg, i.p.) fully prevented the acute down-regulation of Bax (33%) and cytochrome c (31%) induced by the selective I2-ligand LSL 61122 (2 h) in brain cortex (Figure 4). Idazoxan by itself did not modify the basal content of Bax or cytochrome c in rat brain cortex (Figure 4).

caption.p: Effects of pretreatment with idazoxan on LSL 61122-induced down-regulation of mitochondrial Bax and cytochrome c (Cyt c) in rat cerebral cortex. Groups of treatments: saline (n=5), LSL 61122 (10 mg/kg, i.p., 2 h; n=5), idazoxan (10 mg/kg, i.p.) alone (2 h, n=5) or 30 min before LSL 61122 (n=5). Columns are means±SEM of n experiments per group with an animal per experiment and expressed as a percentage of saline-treated rats (control group). One-way ANOVA detected a significant difference between the groups of treatments for Bax [F(3,16)=16.07, p <0.0001] and Cyt c [F(3,16)=4.86, p <0.01]. *p <0.05; **p <0.01 when compared with the corresponding control group, and †p <0.05; †††p <0.001 when compared with the corresponding LSL 61122 group (ANOVA followed by Bonferroni’s test). Bottom panel: representative immunoblots of Bax and Cyt c for each set of experiments (Idx: idazoxan; LSL: LSL 61122; Idx+LSL: idazoxan plus LSL61122) and a representative immunoblot for β-actin as a loading control (saline and I2-drug samples in triplicate). The molecular masses of target proteins were estimated from referenced standards.
LSL: 2-styryl-2-imidazoline; i.p.: intraperitoneal; ANOVA: analysis of variance.

sec.title: Acute and chronic effects of selective I2-imidazoline ligands on the activation of pro-apoptotic JNK1/2 and the cleavage of PARP-1 in the brain
sec.p: The acute (10 mg/kg, 2 h) and chronic (10 mg/kg, every 12 h for seven days) treatments of rats with LSL 61122, 2-BFI and BU-224 did not significantly alter the activation of JNK1/2 (ratio of p-Thr183/Tyr185 JNK to total JNK) in brain cortex (Figure 5A, immunoblots shown for chronic treatments).

caption.p: Acute and chronic effects of 2-BFI, BU-224 LSL 61122 on (A) the activation of JNK1/2 (shown as the ratio of p-Thr183/Tyr185 JNK1/2 to total JNK1/2) and (B) the pattern of proteolytic cleavage of nuclear PARP-1 in rat cerebral cortex. Groups of treatments: saline (n=10), acute I2-drugs (10 mg/kg, i.p., 2 h; n=7), chronic I2-drugs (10 mg/kg, i.p., every 12 h for seven days; n=7). Columns are means±SEM of n experiments per group with an animal per experiment and expressed as a percentage of saline-treated rats (control group). One-way ANOVA did not detect significant differences between the groups of treatments for any I2-drug (F values, p >0.05). Bottom panels (A, B): (A) representative immunoblots of p-JNK1/2 and total JNK1/2 for each set of chronic treatments (saline samples in duplicate; I2-drug samples in triplicate); (B) representative immunoblot of PARP-1 (~116 kDa) cleavage (~85 kDa fragment) for each set of chronic treatments (saline and I2-drug samples in duplicate). PC: positive control (etoposide-induced apoptosis in HL60 cells). NC: negative control (whole cell extract of human HL60 leukaemia cells). IOD: integrated optical density. The molecular masses of target proteins were estimated from referenced standards.

BFI: 2-(2-benzofuranyl)-2-imidazoline; BU-224: 2-(4,5-dihydroimidazol-2-yl)quinolinehydrochloride; LSL: 2-styryl-2-imidazoline; JNK1/2: c-Jun NH2-terminal protein kinase; PARP-1: poly-(ADP-ribose)-polymerase-1; i.p.: intraperitoneal; ANOVA: analysis of variance.

sec.p: On the other hand, the proteolytic cleavage of nuclear PARP-1, assessed through the quantification of 85 kDa fragment, was very similar in saline- and I2-imidazoline ligand-treated rats (relative fragment content; saline: 33 ± 7%; LSL 61122: 28 ± 1%; 2-BFI: 28 ± 2%; BU-224: 30 ± 1%) (Figure 5B). The total amount of PARP-1 was not altered by these drug treatments (Figure 5B, immunoblots shown for chronic treatments).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The major finding of this study demonstrates that chronic treatments with selective I2-imidazoline receptor ligands (LSL 61112, 2-BFI, BU-224) down-regulated the content of pro-apoptotic FADD adaptor, Bax and cytochrome c in rat brain cortex. These results indicate that I2-imidazoline drugs might induce neuroprotective actions through inhibition of key components of canonical apoptotic signalling in the brain (Figure 6).

caption.p: Schematic diagram illustrating the main components of the extrinsic (Fas death receptor) and intrinsic (mitochondrial) apoptotic pathways. See Results and Discussion for specific findings and comments on the acute and chronic regulation of apoptotic proteins by selective I2-imidazoline drugs in rat brain.

sec.p: After induction of Fas receptor aggregates, a DISC is formed by recruitment of FADD adaptor, initiator caspase-8 and FLIPL, a catalytically inactive caspase-8 homologue, which provides a molecular scaffold to transmit death signals with the final activation of effector caspases, such as caspase-3 (García-Fuster et al., 2008b). The acute treatments of rats with LSL 61122 and BU-224 reduced the content of Fas aggregates, p-Ser194 FADD (but not total FADD) and caspase-8 (only with LSL 61122) in brain cortex, which could suggest an attenuation of death receptor signals. In contrast, acute 2-BFI markedly increased Fas aggregates, FADD and p-Ser194 FADD in rat brain cortex. The acute effect of 2-BFI, which suggests the induction of pro-apoptotic actions, might be related to its known indirect dopaminergic activity (Hudson et al., 1999; Sastre-Coll et al., 2001). In fact, the acute activation of the dopaminergic system, directly (D2 receptor agonist) or indirectly (cocaine), has been reported to increase the content of pro-apoptotic FADD in the rat brain (García-Fuster et al., 2009; Álvaro-Bartolomé et al., 2011). However, BU-224 was shown to be much more effective than 2-BFI (20 mg/kg for both drugs) on dopamine release in rat striatum (Hudson et al., 1999), suggesting that other mechanisms, including pharmacokinetic factors, could be involved in the contrasting acute effects of these drugs (with similar affinities for I2-sites; Table 1) on Fas/FADD complex. Notably, however, chronic treatments with 2-BFI and BU-224 were associated with decreases of Fas aggregates, FADD adaptor and/or caspase-8 (only with 2-BFI), which indicated that these selective I2-imidazoline drugs down-regulated key signalling components of the extrinsic apoptotic pathway in the brain. Chronic LSL 61122 only increased cortical FLIPL content, an anti-apoptotic factor that was reduced by chronic 2-BFI. Importantly, chronic 2-BFI and BU-229 also increased the ratio of p-Ser194 FADD to FADD in rat brain cortex. An altered balance between pro-apoptotic FADD and non-apoptotic p-Ser194 FADD (increased p-FADD/FADD ratio; Figure 6) could further favour the neuroplastic/neuroprotective actions induced by some I2-imidazoline drugs (e.g. see Ramos-Miguel et al., 2011).

In the intrinsic apoptotic pathway (Figure 6), the acute treatments of rats with selective and nonselective I2-imidazoline drugs (LSL 61122, 2-BFI, BU-224, LSL 60101, idazoxan) resulted in contrasting changes or no alterations in the content of anti-apoptotic (Bcl-2) or pro-apoptotic (Bax and cytochrome c, both potent caspase-3 activators) mitochrondrial proteins in brain cortex. Importantly, the acute down-regulation of Bax and cytochrome c induced by the selective I2-ligand LSL 61122 was antagonised by idazoxan (see comments below). Notably, chronic treatments with LSL 61122, 2-BFI and BU-224 were associated with decreases of pro-apoptotic Bax and/or cytochrome c in rat brain cortex. Furthermore, chronic LSL 61122 also increased the ratio of Bcl-2 to Bax, an index that measures the balance between cell survival and cell death (Korsmeyer et al., 1993), which suggests that this I2-imidazoline drug preferentially attenuates mitochondrial apoptotic signalling (chronic LSL 61122 only increased anti-apoptotic FLIPL in the extrinsic pathway). Recently, acute 2-BFI (1–6 mg/kg) was also reported to increase Bcl-2 expression in rat brain cortex conferring neuroprotection (i.e. reduction of cell death and infarct size with 1–3 mg/kg) against transient cerebral ischemia (Han et al., 2010). In the current study, acute 2-BFI (10 mg/kg) also up-regulated the content of Bcl-2 protein in the cerebral cortex of naïve rats. Reinforcing the neuroprotective actions of I2-imidazoline drugs in the brain, the acute and/or chronic treatments with LSL 61122, 2-BFI and BU-224 were not associated with aberrant activation of pro-apoptotic JNK1/2 (Dhanasekaran and Reddy, 2008) or increased proteolytic cleavage of nuclear PARP-1, a hallmark of apoptosis, which is mainly mediated by caspase-3 (Kumar, 2007; Chaitanya et al., 2010) (Figure 6). In fact, 2-BFI treatment was reported to reduce the number of caspase-3 positive cells in ischemia-induced rat brain injury (Han et al., 2009).

It is important to note that the compounds BU-224 and 2-BFI are highly selective ligands for I2-binding sites over I1-binding sites (BU-224 is 832-fold selective for I2-sites; Hudson et al., 1999). I1-imidazoline receptors have also been involved in the in vitro regulation of cell death in PC12 pheochromocytoma cells (Dontenwill et al., 2003; Dupuy et al., 2004). In an early study, stimulation of I1-imidazoline receptors with moxonidine was shown to increase pro-apoptotic JNK enzymatic activity in PC12 cells, which was prevented with the I1-receptor antagonist efaroxan (Edwards et al., 2001). In contrast, the selective I2-ligands 2-BFI, BU-224 and LSL 61122 did not activate pro-apoptotic JNK1/2 in rat brain cortex (current results). Although the I1-protein imidazoline receptor antisera (IRAS)/nischarin can function as an anti-apoptotic molecule in PC12 cells reducing the activity of caspase-3 (Dontenwill et al., 2003), other evidence indicates that the selective I1-ligand benazoline potentiates PC12 cell death (through increased caspase-3 activity, blocked by efaroxan) induced by serum deprivation (Dupuy et al., 2004). Recently, chronic moxonidine treatment (9.6 mg/kg/day for one month) has been reported to induce anti-apoptotic actions (Bcl-2 increased; Bax unaltered) in the hamster heart (Stabile et al., 2011). It therefore appears that the chronic activation of I2- or I1-imidazoline receptors is associated with anti-apoptotic actions in vivo. In the present study, it is also worth noting that the compounds LSL 60101 (the imidazole analogue of 2-BFI) and idazoxan (a mixed I2/α2-receptor ligand) did not alter the content of pro- or anti-apoptotic proteins of the extrinsic and intrinsic apoptotic pathways (see comments below).

A shortcoming in the assessment of the in vivo effects of I2-imidazoline drugs is the difficulty in ascribing agonist or antagonist properties for a given drug at I2-receptors. An early study proposed a functional approach to address this problem: the modulation of morphine analgaesia by I2-ligands, which could discriminate agonist and antagonist drug activities according to classic receptor pharmacology (Sánchez-Blázquez et al., 2000). It is known that idazoxan displays very similar affinities for I2-imidazoline sites and α2-adrenoceptor agonist or antagonist sites (Table 1). In functional studies in rats, idazoxan has been demonstrated to be a competitive (orthosteric) antagonist at α2-adrenoceptors (e.g. see Menargues et al., 1990; García-Vallejo et al., 1994). In functional studies in mice (Sánchez-Blázquez et al., 2000), agmatine (an endogenous I2-ligand), LSL 61122, 2-BFI and LSL 60101 behaved as I2-receptor agonists, and idazoxan and BU-224 as silent I2-receptor antagonists. Thus idazoxan and BU-224 (inactive by themselves) completely blocked the potentiation of morphine antinociception induced by agmatine, LSL 61122 and 2-BFI (Sánchez-Blázquez et al., 2000). Similarly, idazoxan also antagonised the potentiation of morphine analgaesia induced by the selective I2-ligand phenyzoline (Gentili et al., 2006). Furthermore, CR4056, a novel I2-imidazoline drug, also showed analgesic efficacy which was blocked by idazoxan (Ferrari et al., 2011). Therefore, idazoxan is a reliable I2-receptor antagonist to fully assess the in vivo effects of selective I2-receptor agonists. In this context, chronic treatment of rats with idazoxan (10 mg/kg, every 12 h for seven days) was shown to increase the density of I2-binding sites in brain cortex (Olmos et al., 1992, 1994). This up-regulation of brain I2-receptor number after repeated idaxozan is consistent with the expected effect of a chronic treatment with an antagonist.

In the current in vivo study, the selective I2-imidazoline ligand LSL 61122 also acted as an I2-receptor agonist (acute down-regulation of pro-apoptotic Bax and cytochrome c) and idazoxan as a silent I2-receptor antagonist (i.e. idazoxan did not modify the basal content of Bax or cytochrome c, but it blocked the effects of LSL 61122). Upon chronic treatments, LSL 61122, 2-BFI and BU-224 also appeared to behave as I2-receptor agonists (i.e. sustained down-regulation of Bax and/or cytochrome c). However, these effects of BU-224 on apoptotic signalling (similar to those of 2-BFI) contrast with other findings indicating that this drug behaved as an I2-receptor antagonist in antinociceptive assays in rats (Sánchez-Blázquez et al., 2000; Thorn et al., 2011). In electrophysiological studies, BU-224 was reported to induce spinal analgaesia (i.e. inhibition of dorsal horn neurones) in rats acting as an I2-receptor agonist, the effect being blocked by idazoxan (Díaz et al., 1997). More recently, BU-224 and 2-BFI were also shown to induce dose-dependent antinociceptive effects in rats, which were antagonised by idazoxan but not by the α2-adrenoceptor antagonist yohimbine (Li et al., 2011). These findings appear to agree well with the current study which indicates that BU-224 behaves as an I2-receptor agonist modulating the content of mitochondrial apoptotic proteins. BU-224 (Finn et al., 2003) and 2-BFI (Tonello et al., 2012) are also reported to display antidepressant-like activity most probably acting as I2-receptor agonists. In the current study, LSL 60101 (the imidazole analogue of 2-BFI) was an inactive compound as a modulator of apoptotic signalling, but it behaved as an I2-receptor agonist potentiating morphine analgaesia in mice (Sánchez-Blázquez et al., 2000) but not in rats (Boronat et al., 1998). Chronic treatment of rats with LSL 60101 was shown to up-regulate the density of I2-binding sites in brain cortex (Alemany et al., 1995), which suggests that this compound could also behave as an I2-receptor antagonist (see above comment for idazoxan). It therefore appears that some I2-imidazoline ligands (e.g. BU-224 and LSL 60101), due to species-related variations and/or chosen target for analysis and/or differences in experimental paradigms, can behave as I2-receptor agonists, low efficacy I2-(partial) agonists or I2-receptor antagonists.

In conclusion, the sustained stimulation of I2-imidazoline receptors with selective drugs might be associated with neuroprotective actions through inhibition of key components of canonical apoptotic signalling (FADD, Bax and/or cytochrome c) and up-regulation of survival anti-apoptotic factors (p-Ser194 FADD/FADD and/or Bcl-2/Bax ratios), which in the long-term could dampen cell death in the brain. These anti-apoptotic mechanisms may work in concert with other molecular mechanisms of neuroprotection (e.g. blockade of NMDA receptors; Olmos et al., 1999) that are engaged by selective I2-imidazoline drugs.

ack.p: The authors thank Dr Rossend Obach and Dr Ángel Menargues (Ipsen Pharma S.A., Barcelona) for gifts of LSL compounds, and Dr Gabriel Martorell (Universitat de les Illes Balears) for NMR analyses of LSL 61122 and LSL 60101. Dr Celia Garau was supported by a postdoctoral contract from RETICS-RTA. Jesús A García-Sevilla is a member of the Institut d’Estudis Catalans (Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain).

The study was supported in part by grants SAF2008-01311 and SAF2011-29918 from the Ministerio de Ciencia e Innovación (MICINN), Ministerio de Economía y Competitividad (MINECO), and Fondo Europeo de Desarrollo Regional (FEDER), Spain. The research was also funded by Redes Temáticas de Investigación Cooperativa en Salud-Red de Trastornos Adictivos (RETICS-RTA, RD06/0001/0003), Instituto de Salud Carlos III (MICINN/MINECO/FEDER, Madrid), Spain.
